awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Experiences in Long Range Communications with Ham Radios, Cool Algorithms, and Innovative Antennas
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site will provide support for eight undergraduate students each summer (24 students over 3 years) to gain research experience under the mentorship of a team of experienced faculty and advanced graduate student researchers in topics related to high frequency (HF) long range wireless communications. Long range HF communications allow wireless communication over thousands of kilometers without the need for satellites, and are of immeasurable importance to military and government, aviation, air-to-ground communications, maritime services, public safety and civil service distress communications, space and satellite operations, weather stations, FM and TV broad casting, and many other communication needs. This REU site will provide participating students a high quality, immersive, and hands-on learning experience in this exciting area. Participants will receive coaching to prepare for graduate school and professional development, and they will be mentored into becoming independent creative thinkers and researchers. Participants will gain experience in scientific dissemination and communication, including publishing in professional conferences and journals, and giving scientific presentations.

Long range HF communications work by the reflection of radio waves by the ionosphere layer of the atmosphere. These communications can travel around curvature of the earth, and work without the need for significant infrastructure like satellites, cellular networks, internet, etc. The challenge with HF communications is that propagation via the ionosphere may be unreliable, the ionospheric conditions may change very rapidly, and different frequencies have different propagation characteristics via the ionosphere. Successful communication depends on the time of day, location of users, selection of frequency, modulation, antenna type, and power level.  This project will generate new solutions to key problems that will enable more dependable and efficient long range HF communications. Specifically this project will investigate and develop: (i) New designs for spectrum agile radios for high frequency communications that can switch communication parameters such as modulation, coding, pulse shape, equalizer, power, etc.; (ii) Machine learning algorithms that can learn the best communication parameters for changing channel conditions; (iii) Low profile antennas that can be used in HF communications; (iv) Software and algorithms to predict network level connections that are possible ahead of time; (v) Qualitative and quantitative Ionospheric communications models; (vi) Flexible and automatic antenna tuning circuits; and (vii) Smart algorithms that can learn from their past experiences in varying Ionospheric conditions, weather situations, time and location.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research for undergraduate (REU) site in Long Range Communications with Ham Radios, Cool Algorithms, and Innovative Antennas aims at introducing students to the fundamentals of systematic research in science and engineering and helping them develop independent thinking and foster their intellectual creativity. Exposure to scientific processes is achieved by conducting research in the area of high-frequency and very high-frequency digital communications and their application to modern technologies such as networking, connected autonomous systems, and security. A total of 21 undergraduates were hosted at the University of Arizona as part of the program. One-third of those students came from underrepresented minority groups. The students attended a 10-week program that included a week of short courses in digital communications, machine learning, networking, security, technical writing, and literature surveying, several seminal talks by UArizona ECE faculty, and weekly student presentations.  The students were also part of the UArizona Undergraduate Research Opportunities Symposium (UROC) which provided them with research training and graduate school preparation through professional development and graduate admission workshops, social networking, community building with like-minded peers, and a free comprehensive GRE workshop.

While at UArizona, the students conducted research on a variety of topics in the area of digital communications including 5G Radio Access Networks, machine learning methods for automatic modulation classification, secure and resilient joint communication-radar-based systems, verification of platooning in connected autonomous systems, and machine learning based multiple input multiple output equalization for high-frequency communications. All students produced a conference-style technical report, a poster, and a video presentation describing their program experience. The main research contributions of the program included (a) a novel physical challenge-response method for verifying vehicle platooning and binding a vehicle’s digital identity with its trajectory (b) a new machine-learning equalizer for multiple input multiple output high-frequency communications that optimizes the equalization algorithm selection in real time, exploiting software-defined radio capabilities, and (c) a reinforcement learning framework for selecting the optimal neural network for performing modulation classification in wireless communications. The research results were disseminated to the research community with two conference publications at international conferences. Moreover, the project provided mentoring opportunities to graduate students who closely mentored the undergraduate research teams in their research, gave tutorials and seminal talks, and also advised students about graduate life.
